user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 8.13.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
If struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header declares header as a non-const pointer (e.g. char *header) and it is used only for read-only access (passed to iterator but not modified), then this violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 because the pointer should be const-qualified (const char *header).
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified MHD_get_response_headers code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/2925.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_response_headers:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN int
MHD_get_response_headers (struct MHD_Response *response,
                          MHD_KeyValueIterator iterator,
                          void *iterator_cls)
{
  int numHeaders = 0;
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos;

  for (pos = response->first_header;
       NULL != pos;
       pos = pos->next)
  {
    numHeaders++;
    if ((NULL != iterator) &&
        (MHD_NO == iterator (iterator_cls,
                             pos->kind,
                             pos->header,
                             pos->value)))
      break;
  }
  return numHeaders;
}
```
</target_code>

<instruction>

Please provide the modified MHD_get_response_headers code.

The information below explains how I’ll use the function you provide. Please use it as a reference when generating code.
1. Replacement
  - I will parse your function and replace the original MHD_get_response_headers with it.
  - Your function must have the exact same signature as MHD_get_response_headers.
  - It must be a complete, self-contained definition; (no omissions, placeholders (e.g., "..."), or comments indicating skipped/omitted logic.)
2. Logging / reachability
  - I will run a test suite that is guaranteed to call MHD_get_response_headers to check logs.
  - Your function MUST preserve the original logic of MHD_get_response_headers as much as possible.
  - The log output must not be empty. Even if you are verifying dead code, MHD_get_response_headers will be reached; insert a minimal probe/log to demonstrate that the target function was entered.
3. Coverage
  - I will run the same test suite to measure coverage.
  - Test outcomes must match those of the original code.
  - If reproducing the rule violation necessarily causes a crash (e.g., the violation inherently triggers a crash), that is acceptable; otherwise, your function should not crash under the existing test suite so coverage can be measured.
4. Test code constraints
  - The test code MUST preserve the original logic of MHD_get_response_headers as much as possible.
  - DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
  - The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
  - The test code MUST include line breaks.
  - You MUST NOT define the main function.
  - You MUST NOT define macros.
  - You MUST NOT REDEFINE any existing identifiers, such as macros, static/global variables, or functions.
  - Do not break string literals or include stray/unmatched double quotes; the code must parse cleanly with no quote-related errors.

These are common mistakes of generated codes. Do not make these mistakes:
- Redefining existing functions, variables, types, or macros.
- Broken string literals or unmatched quotes.
- Invoking undeclared function.
- Using undeclared member in a struct.
- Invoking functions with wrong parameter type.

</instruction>
